Article Title: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff admits, customers still to understand AI as stock continues to be more than 30% down
Article Text:
Stock slump amid AI push



AI adoption still in early stages



Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff sells $546,547 worth of company stock







Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff has acknowledged that many of his enterprise customers are still struggling to understand and implement artificial intelligence, even as the company is increasing its investment in AI-powered platforms. Speaking in an interview with CNBC‚Äôs Jim Cramer at the opening day of Dreameforce 2025, Benioff said that the pace of innovation is already outstripping the awareness and readiness of the customer. ‚ÄúCustomers are getting their head around how to deploy AI,‚Äù Benioff said. ‚ÄúThe speed of innovation is far exceeding the speed of customer adoption.‚ÄùBenioff‚Äôs remarks comes at time when Salesforce shared remain down by more than 30% from their December 2024 peak and 28% lower year-over-year. The company has also faced skepticism from investors despite the roll out of its Agentforce platform. For those unaware, the Agentforce platform uses autonomous AI bots to streamline operations. In August this year, Salesforce also announced that it has reduced its support staff from 9000 to 5000 employees. The company revealed that its decision to cut down jobs was driven by the efficiency gains from AI agents.‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt understand that Agentforce is part and parcel of Salesforce,‚Äù Benioff told Cramer.‚ÄúIt is the core of every product we make now.‚ÄùDuring his keynote at the San Francisco‚Äôs Moscone Center, Benioff revealed that Salesforce‚Äôs clients such as Williams-Sonoma and Pandora have successfully completed the AI integration. But he also added that most of the companies are still facing significant architectural challenges. ‚ÄúThese customers have to go back and modify massive architectures they have and systems they‚Äôre running,‚Äù he said.In related news, Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff sold company shares worth nearly $546,547 on September 26, 2025, Investing.com reported. Citing regulatory filings, the report says that the sale was executed under a pre-arranged trading plan, involving 2,250 shares of common stock sold in multiple transactions at prices ranging from $241.4027 to $244.279. On the same day, Benioff exercised options to buy 2,250 shares of Salesforce at $161.50 each, for a total value of $363,375.After these transactions, Marc Benioff now owns 11,911,571 shares of Salesforce common stock. Indirectly, he owns 10,000,000 shares through the Marc Benioff Fund LLC and 1,07,000 shares by trust.
Article Summary: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff sold $546,547 worth of company stock on September 26, 2025. Salesforce shares remain down by more than 30% from their December 2024 peak and 28% lower year-over-year. In August this year, Salesforce announced that it has reduced its support staff from 9000 to 5000 employees.

Article Title: Proved: America 'pressured' Dutch government to forcefully take control of Chinese chip company
Article Text:
FILE -- President Donald Trump and President Xi Jinping of China at the G20 Summit in Osaka, Japan, June 29, 2019. . (Erin Schaff/The New York Times)

US-China trade tension

Global squeeze on supply chains





In a move that highlights the geopolitical tightrope countries are walking in the US-China battle for technological supremacy, the Dutch government has seized control of a Chinese-owned chip company, Nexperia. The rare takeover, announced this week, follows significant pressure from Washington and has prompted a strong rebuke from Nexperia's parent company.The Dutch government cited ‚Äúserious governance shortcomings‚Äù as the official reason for the takeover. However, court documents published Tuesday reveal a more direct catalyst: American officials had warned the Dutch government that Nexperia's CEO, Zhang Xuezheng, would likely need to be replaced for the company to be removed from the U.S. "entity list," which imposes strict export restrictions. The Amsterdam Court of Appeal document cites minutes from a June meeting between Dutch and American officials, where the U.S. Bureau of International Security and Nonproliferation stated. ‚ÄúThe fact that the company‚Äôs CEO is still the same Chinese owner is problematic,‚Äù the minutes of the meeting said, as cited by the document. ‚ÄúIt is almost certain that the CEO will have to be replaced to qualify for the exemption from the entity list.‚ÄùThe intervention comes as the U.S. and China continue to escalate their tech war. In a recent move, the U.S. Commerce Department expanded its entity list, placing any subsidiary that is at least 50% owned by a blacklisted firm under the same restrictions. This new rule implicated Nexperia, which is a fully-owned subsidiary of Wingtech, a partially state-owned Chinese company that has been on the list since late last year. The Dutch economic ministry took what it called a "highly exceptional" action to prevent Nexperia from making goods that could become unavailable in a crisis.Nexperia, headquartered in Nijmegen, produces lower-end chips used in consumer electronics, automobiles, and industrial applications, and operates facilities in both Germany and the U.K. The company confirmed that following a court order, CEO Zhang Xuezheng has been suspended from his position.The dispute isn't one-sided. In early October, China also imposed export controls, barring Nexperia and its affiliates from exporting certain components manufactured in China. The company is currently seeking an exemption from these restrictions.Wingtech, Nexperia's parent company, has vowed to "never succumb to external political pressure." The company called the Dutch government's takeover "discriminatory treatment" and stated that it has initiated all legal and diplomatic channels to demand the revocation of the decision.
Article Summary: The Dutch government has seized control of a Chinese-owned chip company, Nexperia. The rare takeover follows significant pressure from Washington and has prompted a strong rebuke from Nexperia's parent company. The Dutch government cited "serious governance shortcomings" as the official reason for the takeover. However, court documents reveal a more direct catalyst: American officials had warned the Dutch government the company's CEO would likely need to be replaced.

Article Title: Democrat lawmakers send letter to Google on YouTube's settlement with Donald Trump, say: Public deserves to know whether ...
Article Text:
What is YouTube vs Donald Trump case

What the Democrat lawmakers' letter says





A group of Democrat lawmakers is scrutinizing a $24.5 million settlement between YouTube and President Donald Trump, raising concerns about whether the deal was struck to secure favorable treatment in ongoing antitrust lawsuits against Google , YouTube‚Äôs parent company. In a letter addressed to Google CEO Sundar Pichai and YouTube CEO Neal Mohan, Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-MA), Ron Wyden (D-OR), Bernie Sanders (I-VT), Richard Blumenthal (D-CT), and Jeff Merkley (D-OR) demanded details about the settlement negotiations, according to The Verge.The settlement resolves a 2021 lawsuit filed by Trump after YouTube suspended him from the platform. The Verge notes that the lawsuit‚Äôs legal basis was weak, as courts have consistently upheld social media companies‚Äô rights to ban users. The lawmakers are questioning whether the payout, which includes $22 million allocated for a new White House ballroom, was intended to influence the Trump administration‚Äôs approach to Google‚Äôs antitrust cases.‚ÄúThe public deserves to know whether YouTube‚Äôs settlement will influence the Trump Justice Department‚Äôs decision regarding whether to appeal and seek the stricter remedies DOJ had originally sought against Google,‚Äù the senators wrote, as quoted by the publication, warning that such an arrangement could violate federal anti-bribery laws and California‚Äôs Unfair Competition Law.Google is currently embroiled in multiple antitrust lawsuits, including one concerning its ad tech monopoly, where the Department of Justice has pushed for a potential breakup, and another involving its search business, where milder remedies have been proposed.The report says that the senators are concerned that YouTube‚Äôs settlement of a ‚Äúlegally dubious lawsuit‚Äù might be an attempt to avoid harsher penalties in these cases.The letter follows an earlier inquiry in August, before the settlement was publicized, where the senators warned Google and YouTube against paying for favorable treatment. The companies responded, claiming there were ‚Äúno discussions tying any potential settlement of the case to any official action or to any pending or potential future matters involving Alphabet or any of its affiliates,‚Äù according to the report. The lawmakers are now pressing to verify the accuracy of this statement.YouTube is not alone in settling with Trump. The Verge notes that Paramount paid $16 million amid merger approval talks, while X and Meta settled similar lawsuits for approximately $10 million and $25 million, respectively. Senator Warren previously described Meta‚Äôs settlement as looking ‚Äúlike a bribe,‚Äù the news report said.The scrutiny comes as Trump is set to host a fundraising dinner for the White House ballroom project, according to CBS News, further fueling concerns about the motivations behind these settlements.
Article Summary: A group of Democrat lawmakers is scrutinizing a $24.5 million settlement between YouTube and President Donald Trump. They are concerned that the deal was struck to secure favorable treatment in ongoing antitrust lawsuits against Google. The lawmakers are questioning whether the payout, which includes $22 million allocated for a new White House ballroom, was intended to influence the Trump administration's approach.

Article Title: China is planning to ban 'design feature' that has been the 'hallmark' of Tesla cars since many years
Article Text:
Xiaomi SUV crash raised fears





China‚Äôs Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has reportedly unveiled a draft national standard that could spell the end for hidden door handles, a popular feature in new energy vehicles (NEVs) and some gasoline models, citing safety concerns. According to a report in South China Post, the proposed regulation, released this week, mandates that all passenger car doors, except tailgates, must have exterior handles with a minimum hand-operable space of 60mm x 20mm x 25mm and a mechanical release function.The proposal, if implemented, will effectively ban fully flush, electronically actuated door handles ‚Äî a design Tesla helped popularize and that has since become a hallmark of NEVs. These handles sit flush with the body and extend only when activated. They were designed to cut air drag to extend NEVs' mileage and also give cars a futuristic look.The move aims to enhance vehicle safety, improve passive safety technologies, and protect lives, the ministry stated. Hidden door handles have raised concerns about emergency access. Reports, including an incident involving a Xiaomi SU7, highlight difficulties rescuers face in opening doors during accidents, particularly if sensors fail or power is lost.‚ÄúHidden handles can jam in collisions or fires, complicating rescues,‚Äù an engineer from a domestic carmaker told National Business Daily. Great Wall Motor Chairman Wei Jianjun has also criticized the design‚Äôs reliability. Public data shows about 60% of China‚Äôs top 100 NEVs in April featured these handles, seen in models like the Nio ES8, Li Auto i8, Xiaomi YU7, and XPeng P7.The draft requires doors to be openable without tools, even if the vehicle‚Äôs locking system or battery fails. While hidden handles improve range by 5-10 kilometers, according to an Aion engineer, their futuristic appeal may not outweigh safety risks. Some buyers, particularly older consumers, prefer conventional handles, dealers note.Automakers are bracing for costly redesigns but are ready to comply. Toyota is developing mechanical backups for hidden handles, while Geely, involved in drafting the standard, and Leapmotor have pledged adherence. The proposal includes a transition period: new models must comply within seven months of adoption, and existing models within 19 months.The Chinese ministry is seeking public feedback before finalizing the rule, which analysts say balances urgent safety needs with automakers‚Äô development timelines. If implemented, the standard could reshape vehicle design in China‚Äôs booming NEV market, prioritizing safety over style.
Article Summary: China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has reportedly unveiled a draft national standard that could spell the end for hidden door handles. Hidden door handles have raised concerns about emergency access. Reports, including an incident involving a Xiaomi SU7, highlight difficulties rescuers face in opening doors during accidents.

By expanding AI infrastructure, Google aims to equip Belgian companies and the workforce with advanced digital tools while fostering sustainable and inclusive growth. The investment positions Belgium as a hub for next-generation AI innovation in Europe. It also signals Google‚Äôs commitment to combining technological advancement with environmental responsibility, shaping the future of digital and green growth.

There are also doubts about whether safety mechanisms can fully prevent the creation or distribution of harmful, exploitative, or non-consensual material.Mental health experts have cautioned that exposure to erotic content could trigger psychological distress or addictive behaviours in certain individuals. Meanwhile, legal and regulatory scrutiny is intensifying, with growing calls for stricter oversight of AI platforms that produce adult content.Critics further argue that the introduction of erotica could prioritise commercial interests over responsible AI use, with concerns about unpredictable chatbot behaviour linked to content personalisation. High-profile figures such as billionaire Mark Cuban and politician Vivek Ramaswamy have issued warnings about potential risks to minors, social isolation, and increased addiction, urging a cautious approach and stronger safeguards. This complex mix of enthusiasm and apprehension highlights the challenge OpenAI faces in balancing creative freedom with user safety and ethical responsibility.As OpenAI moves forward with this bold update, its ability to maintain trust while managing moral and regulatory scrutiny will define how society views AI‚Äôs role in adult digital spaces.

Article Title: Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu to take a break from external engagements from next week; says: I am at risk of‚Ä¶
Article Text:
Vembu dedicates 70% of time to coding as chief scientist

Sridhar Vembu could be coding the end-to-end encryption for Arattai





Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu announced on Wednesday that he will step back from external engagements starting next week to focus on coding and product development work he had committed to but fallen behind on. The billionaire entrepreneur said he risks contradicting his own principle of "do not preach what you do not practise" if he continues with external appearances while neglecting hands-on technical work."I have to ship some code I had committed to ship and I have fallen behind. I will take a break from external engagements after this week," Vembu wrote on X (formerly Twitter). "I cannot do both deep tech work (which I am preaching constantly about in my external engagements) and then only do the preaching and not practising it myself.‚ÄùThe announcement comes as Vembu has been increasingly focused on his role as Chief Scientist at Zoho, a position he transitioned to earlier this year after stepping down as CEO in January. In an interview with Moneycontrol, Vembu revealed that he now spends approximately 70% of his time writing and reviewing code, and he wants to increase that proportion even further."I review code every day. In fact, I file a lot of patents. So that's the change in life.I enjoy the life. I'm meant to do this, I feel," Vembu said.The code Vembu is working to ship appears to include end-to-end encryption for Arattai, Zoho's messaging platform. In a series of posts on X earlier this month, Vembu revealed that the feature was originally scheduled for November but has been put on an "accelerated schedule" and is currently in testing.He explained that unlike Zoho Cliq, which stores data in the cloud for business features like search and archiving, Arattai will turn off cloud storage entirely to offer fully encrypted chat that keeps data only on user devices.Vembu emphasised that Zoho's entire SaaS business is built on the trust that the company does not access customer data or use it for selling products, with end-to-end encryption adding an additional technical layer to that commitment.
Article Summary: Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu says he will step back from external engagements starting next week. The billionaire entrepreneur said he risks contradicting his own principle of "do not preach what you do not practise" The code he is working to ship appears to include end-to-end encryption for Arattai, Zoho's messaging platform.

Article Title: Reddit founder Alexis Ohanian says the internet is less human now: ‚ÄòYou all prove‚Ä¶‚Äô
Article Text:
Reddit founder Alexis Ohanian

Reddit founder on dead internet theory

What is dead internet theory





Reddit founder Alexis Ohanian has said that the internet has become less human and more artificial, describing much of it as ‚Äúbotted‚Äù or ‚Äúquasi-AI.‚Äù Speaking on the TBPN podcast recently, Ohanian said what was once a space for real human connection has now turned into something ‚Äúinhuman. ‚Äù ‚ÄúYou all prove the point that so much of the internet is now dead,‚Äù Ohanian told the hosts.During the podcast, he referred to the ‚Äúdead internet theory,‚Äù which suggests that there is now more bot activity than human interaction online. Ohanian said large parts of the web today are filled with automated or AI-generated content, including what he called ‚ÄúLinkedIn slop.‚Äù‚ÄúI think we‚Äôll see a next generation of social media emerge that‚Äôs verifiably human,‚Äù he added.Ohanian said that future platforms will need to focus on real people and live content to stay relevant.‚ÄúThe internet needs to be the opposite of dead ‚Äî with live viewers and live content. Holding attention will require proof of life,‚Äù he said.He also noted that users are already turning to smaller, private spaces to communicate.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all going down in the group chats now,‚Äù Ohanian said, referring to apps like Signal and Discord that people use for more authentic, human conversations.Ohanian added that while these group chats are a sign of what people really want online, they are not new technology.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs got to be some next iteration of that, because that‚Äôs where all of us are getting our really best info now,‚Äù he said.The ‚Äúdead internet theory‚Äù has recently gained attention among tech leaders. It suggests that a large share of online posts, articles, videos, and even social media accounts are generated automatically, giving the illusion of human interaction while actual user activity is far smaller.In September this year, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman posted on X that he ‚Äúnever took the dead internet theory that seriously,‚Äù but now sees ‚Äúa lot of LLM-run Twitter accounts.‚Äù
Article Summary: Reddit founder Alexis Ohanian has said that the internet has become less human and more artificial. Ohanian said large parts of the web today are filled with automated or AI-generated content. He said that future platforms will need to focus on real people and live content.

Article Title: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos‚Äô stake drops to 9%: How his ownership in Amazon declined over years
Article Text:
File photo: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos

Bezos‚Äôs ownership in Amazon over the years





Amazon founder Jeff Bezos ‚Äô ownership in the e-commerce platform has declined to 9%, following a series of stock sales over the past years. In a new filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, the tech billionaire now holds 964.3 million shares of Amazon with sole voting power, and has the authority to dispose of around 883.3 million shares.The latest disclosure comes after Bezos announced plans to sell 25 million Amazon shares through May 2026 earlier this year. As per the SEC filings, he has also made several donations to nonprofit organizations.Bezos‚Äô shareholding has steadily declined over the years ‚Äî from more than 43% when Amazon went public in 1997, to 14.1% when he stepped down as CEO in 2021. In the past two years, Jeff Bezos has sold around $4.8 billion worth of the company‚Äôs stocks.In November last year, Jeff Bezos owned over 1 billion shares, or 10.1% of the company, with the right to sell about 927.5 million of them. According to Amazon‚Äôs annual proxy filing, his stake later dropped to 9.6% in February this year.In July, he offloaded approximately $737 million worth of Amazon stock. In the same month, he sold another 6.6 million shares of the company. The transaction took place on July 21 and 22. The sale was executed under the prearranged trading plan known as Rule 10b5-1.Apart from Amazon, Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post and Blue Origin, his space technology company. His net worth currently stands at $229.7 billion, according to Forbes, making him the world‚Äôs fourth richest person.
Article Summary: Bezos‚Äô shareholding has steadily declined over the years ‚Äî from more than 43% when Amazon went public in 1997, to 14.1% when he stepped down as CEO in 2021. In the past two years, Jeff Bezos has sold around $4.8 billion worth of the company‚Äôs stocks.

Article Title: China issues statement on American technology company it 'punished' on the day Donald Trump announced 100% extra tariff on China
Article Text:
Rising US-China trade tensions on Soyabean and more ...





China broke its silence on the American technology giant Qualcomm that had faced action from Chinese authorities hours before the US President announced his threat to impose 100% extra tariff on China, starting November 1. On October 10, China‚Äôs market regulator State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) launched an anti-monopoly investigation into US semiconductor giant Qualcomm for failing to report its acquisition of Israeli chip designer Autotalks, completed in June 2025. Trump's angry social media post on extra 100% tariff on China came the same day. The US president's post followed a string of tit-for-tat moves by US and China as Presidents Xi Jinping and Donald Trump seemingly look for leverage before a key meeting to discuss trade and other issues.Commenting on probe into Qualcomm, China's market regulator said that the US company has admitted that it had not informed Chinese authorities when it completed its acquisition of Israel's Autotalks in June 2025. The agency said that it had informed Qualcomm in March 2024 that the deal requires approval by the regulator, and the Qualcomm in the same month notified SAMR that it wouldn't pursue further. However, Qualcomm in June this year completed the deal without informing the authority, the regulator said, adding Qualcomm "acknowledged above facts", based on which Beijing launched the antitrust probe.Last week, Beijing‚Äôs Transport Ministry announced on October 10 that it will begin collecting fees on vessels owned by US companies and individuals, as well as those built in America, starting Oct. 14. The move coincides with the date Washington plans to impose new charges on large Chinese ships calling at US ports.Additionally, China tightened export controls on rare earths and other critical materials this week and halted US soybean purchases, moves seen as targeting American industries and communities that supported President Donald Trump in the 2024 election.President Donald Trump on Tuesday, October 14, said that his administration is considering ‚Äúterminating business with China having to do with Cooking Oil‚Äù in retaliation for Beijing refusing to buy US soybeans. China has been the top buyer of U.S. soybeans by far, but it has not bought a single American soybean in months amid an ongoing trade war.
Article Summary: China's market regulator launched an anti-monopoly investigation into US semiconductor giant Qualcomm for failing to report its acquisition of Israeli chip designer Autotalks in June 2025. China's Transport Ministry announced on October 10 that it will begin collecting fees on vessels owned by US companies and individuals, as well as those built in America.
